First of all, one needs to determine the electronic structure of
scheme. In the case of a single magnetic metal ion coordinated
by a set of donor atoms this is accomplished by diagonalizing

atoms is described by the ﬁrst two terms, and its eﬀect is to lift

2 is the free-ion value for the electron Landé
ion. The diagonalization of the Crystal Field
energy levels is based on a model recently developed by some of
us. The full details on the model derivation are rather tedious and
extensive for the present manuscript, but can be found elsewhere
by the readership interested either in reproducing our results
or in studying other molecular systems (

, and the cartesian positions of the
ions in the single crystal. We use
The cartesian positions of the Gd
Since the single crystal used in the EPR experiments contains
ions comparable to an Avogadro’s number,
which is too large to be handled in a computer, we extract several
spherical clusters with increasing radii of hundreds of Å fromthe
single crystal. For each given pair of energy levels, we calculated
at each one of these clusters and found that, for a large enough
converges to a limit value. This means that including
ions beyond the converging cluster radius does
not produce any eﬀect on the calculated
proves that there is no need to deal with the whole single crystal.
A radius of 400 Å was enough to converge the calculated
each pair of energy levels explored.
The simulation of a given concentration below 100% implies
to remove a proper number of Gd
. Since the working concentration of the
single crystal employed in the EPR experiments was 1%, this
means that we need to remove 99 out of 100 Gd
ions and at each one we generate a
the ion position; otherwise, we drop it. This results in a random
dilution that matches the desired concentration. Nonetheless,
there does not exist of course a unique way to randomly distribute
